metadata.section_title: Validity requirements for the Private Life route

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for the Private Life route

PL 1.1. A person applying for permission to stay on the Private Life route must apply online on the gov.uk website on the specified form: “Application to remain in the UK on the basis of family life or private life”.

1.   PL 1.2. An application for permission to stay on the Private Life route must meet all the following validity requirements: 
    1.   (a) any fee and Immigration Health Charge must have been paid (unless the applicant has been granted a fee waiver in whole or in part); and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided a passport or other document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application.

2.   PL 1.3. If a private life claim is made under Article 8 of the Human Rights Convention and it is made: 
    1.   (a) at the same time as a protection claim or further submission in person after a protection claim has been refused; or
    2.   (b) when the applicant is in detention (and the claim is submitted to a prison officer, custody officer or a member of Home Office staff at the place of detention); or
    3.   (c) during an appeal (subject to the consent of the Secretary of State where applicable), the requirements at PL 1.1. and at PL 1.2. (a) and (c) will be waived.

PL 1.4. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for the Private Life route may be rejected as invalid and not considered.
chunks.summary: Applicants seeking permission to stay under the Private Life route must apply online, pay applicable fees and health charges (or obtain waivers), provide biometrics and proof of identity, and be physically present in the UK at the time of application. Certain claims made under Article 8 during detention, appeals, or with protection claims may be exempt from these requirements.

PL 2.1. The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

PL 2.2. DELETED.

chunks.summary: This provision applies to applicants seeking entry or settlement via the Private Life route. It requires demonstrating sufficient integration, relationship stability, or existing private life ties, with exceptions or thresholds applicable based on age, health, or length of residence in the UK.

metadata.section_title: Residence requirements for a child on the Private Life route

chunks.text:
### Residence requirements for a child on the Private Life route

1.   PL 3.1. Where the applicant is aged under 18 at the date of application the following requirements must be met: 
    1.   (a) the applicant must have been continuously resident in the UK for at least 7 years; and
    2.   (b) the decision maker must be satisfied that it would not be reasonable to expect the applicant to leave the UK.
chunks.summary: Applicants under 18 applying via the Private Life route must have been continuously resident in the UK for at least 7 years, and it must be unreasonable to expect them to leave, under UK Immigration Rules.

metadata.section_title: Residence requirements for a young adult on the Private Life route (where the applicant arrived in the UK as a child)

chunks.text:
### Residence requirements for a young adult on the Private Life route (where the applicant arrived in the UK as a child)

PL 4.1. Where the applicant is aged 18 or over and aged under 25 at the date of application and arrived in the UK before the age of 18, the applicant must have spent at least half their life continuously resident in the UK.
chunks.summary: Applicants aged 18-24 applying under the Private Life route must have spent at least half their life continuously in the UK, provided they arrived before age 18. The requirement emphasizes long-term residence, with no specified exceptions.

metadata.section_title: Residence requirements for an adult on the Private Life route

chunks.text:
### Residence requirements for an adult on the Private Life route (including a young adult who does not qualify under PL 4.1.)

1.   PL 5.1. Where the applicant is aged 18 or over on the date of application: 
    1.   (a) the applicant must have been continuously resident in the UK for more than 20 years; or
    2.   (b) where the applicant has not been continuously resident in the UK for more than 20 years, the decision maker must be satisfied there would be very significant obstacles to the applicant’s integration into the country where they would have to live if required to leave the UK.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to adult applicants on the Private Life route, including certain young adults. They must have over 20 years of continuous UK residence or face very significant obstacles to integration elsewhere; exceptions may apply if these conditions are not met.

metadata.section_title: Exclusion of certain asylum seekers

chunks.text:
### Exclusion of certain asylum seekers

PL 6.1. An applicant who has made a protection or asylum claim which has been declared inadmissible under Part 11 of these rules before 28 June 2022, or under section 80B and 80C of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002, and which continues to be treated as inadmissible, cannot meet the requirement at PL 5.1(b).
chunks.summary: This provision applies to asylum seekers with inadmissible claims declared before 28 June 2022. Such applicants cannot satisfy the requirements under PL 5.1(b). The rule excludes these individuals from certain protections or pathways outlined in the Immigration Rules.

metadata.section_title: Continuous residence period

chunks.text:
### Continuous Residence requirements on the Private Life route

PL 7.1. The period of continuous residence at PL 3.1, PL 4.1. or PL 5.1. may include time spent in the UK with or without permission.

PL 7.2. The period of continuous residence at PL 3.1, PL 4.1. or PL 5.1. does not include any period of imprisonment or detention where the applicant was convicted of an offence and sentenced to a period of imprisonment or was directed to be detained in an institution other than a prison.

1.   PL 7.3. The period of continuous residence at PL 3.1, PL 4.1. or PL 5.1 is broken (i.e. is no longer continuous) if any of the following apply: 
    1.   (a) the applicant has been absent from the UK for more than 6 months at any one time; or
    2.   (b) the applicant has spent a total of 550 days or more absent from the UK during the period of continuous residence at PL 3.1, PL 4.1 or PL 5.1; or
    3.   (c) the applicant has been removed, deported or has left the UK having had an application for permission to enter or stay in the UK refused; or
    4.   (d) the applicant left the UK with no reasonable expectation at the time of leaving that they would lawfully be able to return.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to applicants applying under the Private Life route. It requires maintaining continuous residence in the UK, excluding periods of imprisonment, with specific thresholds: absences over 6 months or totaling 550 days break continuity. Exceptions include removals, deportations, or leaving without reasonable expectation of returning.

    4.   (d) the applicant left the UK with no reasonable expectation at the time of leaving that they would lawfully be able to return.

metadata.section_title: Eligibility requirement for Private Life route relying on Article 8 of the Human Rights Convention

chunks.text:
### Eligibility requirement for Private Life route relying on Article 8 of the Human Rights Convention

PL 8.1. If the applicant does not meet the suitability requirements (subject to PL 8.2), or does not meet any of the eligibility requirements in PL 3.1., PL 4.1. or PL 5.1. the decision maker must be satisfied that refusal of permission to stay would not breach Article 8 of the Human Rights Convention on the basis of private life.

PL 8.2. Where PL 8.1. applies and the applicant falls for refusal under SUI 2.1. SUI 3.1., SUI 4.1., or SUI 5.1. of Part Suitability the application on the Private Life route will be refused.
chunks.summary: Applicants seeking leave under the Private Life route relying on Article 8 must not fail suitability or other specific eligibility requirements; otherwise, their application will be refused. If these criteria are met, decision-makers must ensure refusal would breach Article 8, unless the applicant falls under certain suitability or eligibility exclusion thresholds.

metadata.section_title: Decision on an application on the Private Life route

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application on the Private Life route

PL 9.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all the suitability requirements are met and the eligibility requirements at PL 3.1, PL 4.1, PL 5.1 or PL.8.1. are met then, unless paragraph PL 8.2. applies, the applicant will be granted permission to stay on the Private Life route, otherwise the application will be refused.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to applicants on the Private Life route. If they meet all suitability and eligibility requirements, and no exceptional refusal grounds apply, they will be granted permission to stay; otherwise, their application will be refused.

### Decision on an application on the Private Life route

PL 9.1. If the decision maker is satisfied that all the suitability requirements are met and the eligibility requirements at PL 3.1, PL 4.1, PL 5.1 or PL.8.1. are met then, unless paragraph PL 8.2. applies, the applicant will be granted permission to stay on the Private Life route, otherwise the application will be refused.

metadata.section_title: Period of grant for permission to stay on the Private Life route

chunks.text:
### Period of grant for permission to stay on the Private Life route

1.   PL 10.1. If the applicant is under 18 at the date of application (or was under 18 when first granted permission on the private life route), they will be granted permission to stay for either: 
    1.   (a) 30 months, where the applicant has applied for a period of 30 months; or
    2.   (b) 60 months, where the applicant has applied for a period of 60 months.

2.   PL 10.2. If the applicant is a young adult who has spent half their life in the UK at the date of application (or was previously granted as a young adult on the private life route), they will be granted permission to stay for either: 
    1.   (a) 30 months, where the applicant has applied for a period of 30 months; or
    2.   (b) 60 months, where the applicant has applied for a period of 60 months.

PL 10.3. In all other cases the applicant will be granted 30 months permission to stay.

PL 10.4. Where a person is seeking to extend their permission to stay, any remaining period of permission at the date of application will be added to their next grant of permission, up to a maximum of 28 days.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to applicants on the UK Private Life route. It requires grants of permission to stay for 30 or 60 months based on age and residence history, with extensions adding remaining periods up to 28 days; exceptions apply for other cases, which grant 30 months.

    1.   (a) 30 months, where the applicant has applied for a period of 30 months; or
    2.   (b) 60 months, where the applicant has applied for a period of 60 months.

PL 10.3. In all other cases the applicant will be granted 30 months permission to stay.

PL 10.4. Where a person is seeking to extend their permission to stay, any remaining period of permission at the date of application will be added to their next grant of permission, up to a maximum of 28 days.

metadata.section_title: Conditions of grant for the Private Life route

chunks.text:
### Conditions of grant for the Private Life route

1.   PL 10.5. The grant of permission will be subject to the following conditions: 
    1.   (a) work (including self-employment and voluntary work) permitted; and
    2.   (b) study is permitted, subject to the ATAS condition in Appendix ATAS; and
    3.   (c) if the decision maker is satisfied that: 
        1.   (i) the applicant is destitute, as defined in section 95 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999, or is at risk of imminent destitution; or
        2.   (ii) there are reasons relating to the welfare of a relevant child which outweigh the considerations for imposing or maintaining the condition (treating the best interests of a relevant child as a primary consideration), or
        3.   (iii) the applicant is facing exceptional circumstances affecting their income or expenditure,

    4.   then the applicant will not be subject to a condition of no access to public funds. If the decision maker is not so satisfied, the applicant will be subject to a condition of no access to public funds.

2.   PL 10.6. For the purposes of PL 10.5.(c)(ii) ‘relevant child’ means a person who: 
    1.   (a) is under the age of 18 years at the date of application; and
    2.   (b) it is clear from the information provided by the applicant, is a child who would be affected by a decision to impose or maintain the no access to public funds condition.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to applicants granted permission under the Private Life route. It requires that work and study are permitted, with exceptions for destitution, child welfare, or exceptional circumstances, which may waive restrictions on access to public funds. Critical conditions include assessments of destitution or welfare considerations affecting minors under 18.

metadata.section_id: Settlement on the Private Life route
metadata.section_title: Settlement on the Private Life route

chunks.text: ### Settlement on the Private Life route
chunks.summary: This provision applies to individuals seeking settlement via the Private Life route. It requires applicants to demonstrate established, long-standing private life in the UK, typically lasting at least 10 years, with limited exceptions. The rules specify thresholds and conditions for granting settlement based on duration and circumstances.

Summary: This provision applies to individuals seeking settlement via the Private Life route. It requires applicants to demonstrate established, long-standing private life in the UK, typically lasting at least 10 years, with limited exceptions. The rules specify thresholds and conditions for granting settlement based on duration and circumstances.

### Settlement on the Private Life route

metadata.section_title: Validity requirements for settlement on the Private Life route

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for settlement on the Private Life route

PL 11.1. A person on the Private Life route who is applying for settlement must apply online on the gov.uk website on the specified form as follows:

| Adult (aged 18 or over) | Settlement on the private life route |
| --- | --- |
| Child (aged under 18) | Settlement as a child (including a child aged over 18 already in the UK as a dependent) |

1.   PL 11.2. An application for settlement must meet all the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) any fee must have been paid; and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided a passport or other travel document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application.

1.   PL 11.3. An applicant must have, or have last been granted, permission on the Private Life route, unless: 
    1.   (a) they are a child who was born in the UK; or
    2.   (b) they are a child who has, or last had, permission as a dependent child (under Appendix FM or leave outside the Immigration Rules), before 20 June 2022 and would have met the continuous residence requirements in paragraph PL 3.1(a) at the time that permission or leave was granted; or
    3.   (c) they are over the age of 18 and meet or met the half-life test, and has, or last had, permission on the basis of their family or private life (under Appendix FM or with leave outside the Immigration Rules), before 20 June 2022.

PL 11.4. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for settlement on the Private Life route may be rejected as invalid and not considered.
chunks.summary: Applicants aged 18 or over or children in the UK applying for settlement via the Private Life route must submit an online application, pay fees, provide biometrics and travel documents, and be in the UK at application time. They must have current or previous permission on this route unless they are UK-born children, children with prior permission as dependents, or over 18 meeting the half-life test.

metadata.section_title: Suitability requirements for settlement on the Private Life route

chunks.text:
### Suitability requirements for settlement on the Private Life route

PL 12.1. The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

PL 12.2. DELETED.

PL 12.3. The applicant must not fall for refusal under SUI 5.3. of Part Suitability, unless the applicant has completed a qualifying period of 10 years continuous residence with permission as set out in PL 12.6. and has completed 5 years continuous residence with such permission since the end of their sentence.

1.   PL 12.4. Where any of the following occur during the applicant’s qualifying period for settlement, the applicant must be refused settlement unless the applicant has completed a continuous qualifying period of 10 years with permission as set out in PL 12.6. and has completed 5 years continuous residence with such permission after the date of the first grant of permission after the suitability ground came to the attention of the decision maker: 
    1.   (a) involvement in a sham marriage or civil partnership (SUI 8.1. of Part Suitability); or
    2.   (b) use of false documents or information or deception (SUI 9.1. and SUI 10.1. of Part Suitability); or
    3.   (c) litigation debt owed to the Home Office, unless the debt has been paid (SUI 17.1. of Part Suitability); or
    4.   (d) debt to the NHS, unless the debt has been paid, or the total value of outstanding charges is under £500 (SUI 16.1. of Part Suitability); or
    5.   (e) the applicant has breached the conditions of their permission (SUI 11.1. of Part Suitability).

PL 12.5. Unless the applicant is a child or young adult who was granted permission to stay on the basis of private life under paragraphs PL 3.1. or PL 4.1, if the applicant entered the UK illegally settlement must be refused unless the applicant has completed a qualifying period of 10 years with permission under PL 12.6.

1.   PL 12.6. Where an applicant must complete a qualifying period of 10 years continuous residence (under PL 12.3. to PL 12.5.), they must have had permission as (or as a combination of) the following for that 10 year qualifying period: 
    1.   (a) entry clearance or permission granted as a partner or parent under Appendix FM (except for permission as a fiancé(e) or proposed civil partner); or
    2.   (b) permission described in the Home Office grant letter as “family permission as a parent” or “family permission as a partner”; or
    3.   (c) permission on the private life route under paragraph 276ADE or 276BE(2) before 20 June 2022 or Appendix Private Life; or
    4.   (d) entry clearance or permission as a child of a person with limited leave as a partner or parent under Appendix FM; or
    5.   (e) permission granted outside the rules as a partner, a parent or child or because of private life on the basis of Article 8 of the Human Rights Convention.

2.   PL 12.7. The applicant must not be: 
    1.   (a) in breach of immigration laws, except that where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, that period of overstaying will be disregarded; or
    2.   (b) on immigration bail.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to applicants seeking settlement on the Private Life route. They must not be refused under Part Suitability, with specific conditions allowing for exceptions after completing a 10-year continuous residence, including certain misconduct or debts, provided additional residency criteria are met. Notably, involvement in sham marriages, deception, or unpaid debts during the qualifying period generally lead to refusal unless thresholds are satisfied.

metadata.section_id: Eligibility requirements for settlement on the Private Life route
metadata.section_title: Eligibility requirements for settlement on the Private Life route

chunks.text: ### Eligibility requirements for settlement on the Private Life route
chunks.summary: This provision applies to applicants seeking settlement via the Private Life route. It requires them to demonstrate continuous lawful residence and meet specific criteria, with exceptions for certain vulnerable groups, ensuring eligibility conditions are satisfied for settlement approval.
chunks.augmented_text:

Section ID: Eligibility requirements for settlement on the Private Life route
Section: Eligibility requirements for settlement on the Private Life route
Topic: eligibility

Summary: This provision applies to applicants seeking settlement via the Private Life route. It requires them to demonstrate continuous lawful residence and meet specific criteria, with exceptions for certain vulnerable groups, ensuring eligibility conditions are satisfied for settlement approval.

### Eligibility requirements for settlement on the Private Life route

metadata.section_title: Child born in the UK requirements for settlement on the Private life route

chunks.text:
### Child born in the UK requirements for settlement on the Private life route

PL 13.1. The applicant must have been born in the UK and must provide a full UK birth certificate.

PL 13.2. The applicant must have lived continuously in the UK since their birth and for at least 7 years at the date of application.

PL 13.3. The decision maker must be satisfied that it is not reasonable to expect the applicant to leave the UK.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children born in the UK applying for settlement on the private life route. Applicants must have been born in the UK, provide a birth certificate, and have lived continuously in the UK for at least 7 years; the decision also considers whether it is reasonable for the child to leave the UK.

### Child born in the UK requirements for settlement on the Private life route

PL 13.1. The applicant must have been born in the UK and must provide a full UK birth certificate.

PL 13.2. The applicant must have lived continuously in the UK since their birth and for at least 7 years at the date of application.

PL 13.3. The decision maker must be satisfied that it is not reasonable to expect the applicant to leave the UK.

metadata.section_title: Qualifying period requirement for settlement on the Private Life route (where the applicant was not born in the UK)

chunks.text:
### Qualifying period requirement for settlement on the Private Life route (where the applicant was not born in the UK)

PL 14.1. An applicant who has, or last had, permission to stay on the private life route as a child, or young adult who met the half-life test under PL 4.1, must have lived in the UK for a continuous qualifying period of 5 years with permission as set out in PL 14.3 or 14.4.

1.   PL 14.1A. A child applicant who has, or last had, permission as a dependent child under Appendix FM or leave outside the Immigration Rules before 20 June 2022, and would have met the private life rules at the time they were granted that permission, must: 
    1.   (a) meet the continuous residence requirements for a child at PL 3.1(a) at the date of application or have met the continuous residence requirements for a child at PL 3.1(a) in a previous application; and
    2.   (b) have lived in the UK for a continuous qualifying period of 5 years with permission as set out in PL 14.3.

PL 14.1B. The periods at PL 14.1A(a) and (b) must not run concurrently.

1.   PL 14.2. An applicant who is aged 18 or over at the date of application and does not meet the requirement in PL 14.1., must either: 
    1.   (a) have lived in the UK for a continuous qualifying period of 10 years with permission set out in PL 14.3. or 14.4.; or
    2.   (b) have, or last had, permission on the basis of their family or private life (under Appendix FM or leave outside the Immigration Rules before 20 June 2022), before 20 June 2022.

1.   PL 14.2A. Where 14.2(b) applies, the applicant must have lived in the UK for a continuous qualifying period of 5 years with permission as set out in PL 14.3, and either: 
    1.   (a) meet the half-life test at PL 4.1. at the date of application; or
    2.   (b) have met the half-life test at PL 4.1. in a previous application, or;
    3.   (c) have been initially granted permission as a child (as set out in PL 14.3.) and have since turned 25 and have spent at least half their life continuously resident in the UK.

1.   PL 14.3. Permission on the following routes (or any combination of those routes) counts towards the qualifying period in PL 14.1, PL 14.2 or PL 14.2A: 
    1.   (a) entry clearance or permission granted as a partner or parent under Appendix FM (except for permission as a fiancé(e) or proposed civil partner); or
    2.   (b) permission described in the Home Office grant letter as “family permission as a parent” or “family permission as a partner”; or
    3.   (c) permission on the private life route under paragraph 276ADE or 276BE(2) before 20 June 2022 or Appendix Private Life; or
    4.   (d) entry clearance or permission as a child of a person with limited leave as a partner or parent under Appendix FM; or
    5.   (e) permission granted outside the rules as a partner, a parent or child or because of private life on the basis of Article 8 of the Human Rights Convention.

2.   PL 14.4. Permission on any other route that includes rules allowing an applicant to qualify for settlement also counts towards the qualifying period in PL 14.1. or PL 14.2, if the applicant: 
    1.   (a) did not enter the UK illegally (unless they have permission to stay on the private life route as a child or young adult); and
    2.   (b) has had permission either under paragraph 276ADE or 276 BE(2) before 20 June 2022 or Appendix Private Life for at least one year at the date of application.
chunks.summary: Applicants under the private life route must have lived continuously in the UK for 5 years (if previously granted as a child or young adult meeting the half-life test) or 10 years if over 18 without meeting the half-life test, with relevant permission. Certain conditions apply for child applicants and those whose permissions predate June 2022, with specific residency and permission requirements outlined in PL 14.1 and PL 14.2.

Certain conditions apply for child applicants and those whose permissions predate June 2022, with specific residency and permission requirements outlined in PL 14.1 and PL 14.2.

### Qualifying period requirement for settlement on the Private Life route (where the applicant was not born in the UK)

PL 14.1. An applicant who has, or last had, permission to stay on the private life route as a child, or young adult who met the half-life test under PL 4.1, must have lived in the UK for a continuous qualifying period of 5 years with permission as set out in PL 14.3 or 14.4.

1.   PL 14.1A. A child applicant who has, or last had, permission as a dependent child under Appendix FM or leave outside the Immigration Rules before 20 June 2022, and would have met the private life rules at the time they were granted that permission, must: 
    1.   (a) meet the continuous residence requirements for a child at PL 3.1(a) at the date of application or have met the continuous residence requirements for a child at PL 3.1(a) in a previous application; and
    2.   (b) have lived in the UK for a continuous qualifying period of 5 years with permission as set out in PL 14.3.

PL 14.1B. The periods at PL 14.1A(a) and (b) must not run concurrently.

1.   PL 14.2. An applicant who is aged 18 or over at the date of application and does not meet the requirement in PL 14.1., must either: 
    1.   (a) have lived in the UK for a continuous qualifying period of 10 years with permission set out in PL 14.3. or 14.4.; or
    2.   (b) have, or last had, permission on the basis of their family or private life (under Appendix FM or leave outside the Immigration Rules before 20 June 2022), before 20 June 2022.

1.   PL 14.2A. Where 14.2(b) applies, the applicant must have lived in the UK for a continuous qualifying period of 5 years with permission as set out in PL 14.3, and either: 
    1.   (a) meet the half-life test at PL 4.1. at the date of application; or
    2.   (b) have met the half-life test at PL 4.1. in a previous application, or;
    3.   (c) have been initially granted permission as a child (as set out in PL 14.3.) and have since turned 25 and have spent at least half their life continuously resident in the UK.

1.   PL 14.3. Permission on the following routes (or any combination of those routes) counts towards the qualifying period in PL 14.1, PL 14.2 or PL 14.2A: 
    1.   (a) entry clearance or permission granted as a partner or parent under Appendix FM (except for permission as a fiancé(e) or proposed civil partner); or
    2.   (b) permission described in the Home Office grant letter as “family permission as a parent” or “family permission as a partner”; or
    3.   (c) permission on the private life route under paragraph 276ADE or 276BE(2) before 20 June 2022 or Appendix Private Life; or
    4.   (d) entry clearance or permission as a child of a person with limited leave as a partner or parent under Appendix FM; or
    5.   (e) permission granted outside the rules as a partner, a parent or child or because of private life on the basis of Article 8 of the Human Rights Convention.

2.   PL 14.4. Permission on any other route that includes rules allowing an applicant to qualify for settlement also counts towards the qualifying period in PL 14.1. or PL 14.2, if the applicant: 
    1.   (a) did not enter the UK illegally (unless they have permission to stay on the private life route as a child or young adult); and
    2.   (b) has had permission either under paragraph 276ADE or 276 BE(2) before 20 June 2022 or Appendix Private Life for at least one year at the date of application.

metadata.section_title: Continuous Residence requirement for settlement on the Private Life route

chunks.text:
### Continuous Residence requirement for settlement on the Private Life route

PL 15.1. The applicant must meet the continuous residence requirements as set out in Appendix Continuous Residence for the qualifying period for settlement, unless they are a child born in the UK.
chunks.summary: Applicants seeking settlement on the Private Life route must meet the continuous residence requirement over the qualifying period, except if they are a UK-born child; compliance with Appendix Continuous Residence is essential.

### Continuous Residence requirement for settlement on the Private Life route

PL 15.1. The applicant must meet the continuous residence requirements as set out in Appendix Continuous Residence for the qualifying period for settlement, unless they are a child born in the UK.

metadata.section_title: Continuous residence requirements for a child born in the UK applying for settlement on the Private Life route

chunks.text:
### Continuous residence requirements for a child born in the UK applying for settlement on the Private Life route

PL 15A.1. The period of continuous residence at PL 13.2. may include time spent in the UK with or without permission.

PL 15A.2. The period of continuous residence at PL 13.2. does not include any period during which the applicant was serving a sentence of imprisonment or was detained in an institution other than a prison.

1.   PL 15A.3. The period of continuous residence at PL 13.2. is broken (i.e. is no longer continuous) if any of the following apply: 
    1.   (a) the applicant has been absent from the UK for more than 6 months at any one time; or
    2.   (b) the applicant has spent a total of 550 days or more absent from the UK during the period of continuous residence at PL 13.2.; or
    3.   (c) the applicant has been removed, deported or has left the UK having had an application for permission to enter or stay in the UK refused; or
    4.   (d) the applicant left the UK with no reasonable expectation at the time of leaving that they would lawfully be able to return.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children born in the UK applying for settlement via the Private Life route. It requires them to have maintained continuous residence, with permitted absences under certain limits (no more than 6 months at a time or 550 days total), excluding periods of detention; breaks occur if these thresholds are exceeded or if they have been removed or left unlawfully.

metadata.section_title: English language requirement for settlement on the Private Life route

chunks.text:
### English language requirement for settlement on the Private Life route

PL 16.1. Unless an exemption applies (for example where the applicant is aged under 18), the applicant must show English language ability on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages in speaking and listening to at least level B1.

PL 16.2. The applicant must show they meet the English language requirement as specified in Appendix English Language.
chunks.summary: Applicants seeking settlement on the Private Life route must demonstrate English language ability at B1 level in speaking and listening, unless exempt (e.g., under 18). They must meet the standards set in Appendix English Language, with specific exemptions applying.

metadata.section_title: Decision on an application for settlement on the Private Life route

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application for settlement on the Private Life route

PL 18.1. If the decision maker is satisfied the suitability and eligibility requirements for settlement on the Private Life route are met the applicant will be granted settlement.

1.   PL 18.2. If the requirements for settlement are not met, but the decision maker believes the applicant is likely to meet all the suitability and eligibility requirements for permission to stay on the private life route the application will be varied by the Secretary of State to an application for permission to stay on the private life route. Where this happens: 
    1.   (a) no additional application fee for permission to stay will be required and the settlement application fee will not be refunded; and
    2.   (b) the Secretary of State will write to the applicant informing them of this variation and if required will request the applicant pay any Immigration Health Charge.

PL 18.3. If the applicant does not pay the requested Immigration Health Charge or does not request a fee waiver for the Immigration Health Charge which is then granted, the application for permission to stay will be rejected as invalid and the applicant will not be refunded the fee paid for the settlement application.

PL 18.4. Where an applicant is granted permission to stay they will be granted for a period as set out in PL 10.1. to 10.4. (as relevant), subject to the conditions in PL 10.5.

PL 18.5. If the decision maker is not satisfied that the applicant meets all the suitability and eligibility requirements for settlement or permission to stay the application for settlement on the Private Life route will be refused.
chunks.summary: Applicants applying for settlement via the Private Life route must meet suitability and eligibility criteria for approval. If criteria are not fully met but likely to be, their application may be varied to permission to stay without additional fee, provided they pay the Immigration Health Charge; failure to pay or request a waiver results in invalid rejection. Successful applicants are granted permission to stay for a specified period subject to conditions.

chunks.text: ### Dependent child born in the UK to a person on the Private Life Route
chunks.summary: This provision applies to dependent children born in the UK to individuals on the Private Life Route. It requires the child to meet specific eligibility criteria for settled or qualifying status. Key conditions include demonstrating the child's dependency and, in some cases, meeting continuous residence or relationship thresholds.

metadata.section_title: Validity requirements for a child born in the UK to a person on the Private Life route

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for a child born in the UK to a person on the Private Life route

PL 19.1. A person applying for permission to stay as a child born in the UK to a person on the Private Life route must apply online on the gov.uk website on the specified form: “Application to remain in the UK on the basis of family life or private life”.

1.   PL 19.2. An application for permission to stay as a child born in the UK to a person on the Private Life route must meet all the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) any fee and Immigration Health Charge must have been paid (unless a fee waiver has been granted in whole or in part); and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided a passport or other document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must be applying as a child of a person (P) on the Private Life route who: 
        1.   (i) has made a valid application for permission to stay in the UK on the Private Life route that has not been decided; or
        2.   (ii) has permission to stay on the Private Life route; or
        3.   (iii)is settled or has become a British citizen, providing P had permission to stay on the Private Life route when they settled, and the applicant was born before P settled; and

    5.   (e) the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application.

PL 19.3. An applicant must be aged under 18 at the date of application.

1.   PL 19.4. If a claim is made under Article 8 of the Human Rights Convention: 
    1.   (a) at the same time as a protection claim or further submission in person after a protection claim is refused; or
    2.   (b) in an appeal (subject to the consent of the Secretary of State where applicable); the requirements at PL 19.1. and at PL 19.2. (a) and (c) will be waived.

PL 19.5. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for a child born in the UK of a person on the Private Life route may be rejected as invalid and not considered.
chunks.summary: Applicants seeking permission to stay in the UK as a child born to a person on the Private Life route must apply online, meet fee, biometric, and identity requirements, and be under 18 on application date. The child's parent must have an active or settled Private Life route status, and the child must be in the UK at the time of application.

### Validity requirements for a child born in the UK to a person on the Private Life route

PL 19.1. A person applying for permission to stay as a child born in the UK to a person on the Private Life route must apply online on the gov.uk website on the specified form: “Application to remain in the UK on the basis of family life or private life”.

1.   PL 19.2. An application for permission to stay as a child born in the UK to a person on the Private Life route must meet all the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) any fee and Immigration Health Charge must have been paid (unless a fee waiver has been granted in whole or in part); and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided a passport or other document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must be applying as a child of a person (P) on the Private Life route who: 
        1.   (i) has made a valid application for permission to stay in the UK on the Private Life route that has not been decided; or
        2.   (ii) has permission to stay on the Private Life route; or
        3.   (iii)is settled or has become a British citizen, providing P had permission to stay on the Private Life route when they settled, and the applicant was born before P settled; and

    5.   (e) the applicant must be in the UK on the date of application.

PL 19.3. An applicant must be aged under 18 at the date of application.

1.   PL 19.4. If a claim is made under Article 8 of the Human Rights Convention: 
    1.   (a) at the same time as a protection claim or further submission in person after a protection claim is refused; or
    2.   (b) in an appeal (subject to the consent of the Secretary of State where applicable); the requirements at PL 19.1. and at PL 19.2. (a) and (c) will be waived.

PL 19.5. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for a child born in the UK of a person on the Private Life route may be rejected as invalid and not considered.

metadata.section_title: Period of grant as a child born in the UK to a person on the Private Life route

chunks.text:
### Period of grant as a child born in the UK to a person on the Private Life route

PL 24.1. The applicant will be granted permission to stay which ends on the same date as whichever of their parents’ permission ends first unless the other parent is a British citizen or a person who has a right to enter or stay in the UK without restriction and is or will be ordinarily resident in the UK. In such cases, the applicant will be granted permission to stay which ends on the same date as the parent on the Private Life route.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children born in the UK to parents on the Private Life route. They are granted permission until their parent’s permission ends, unless a parent is a British citizen or has indefinite UK residence, in which case their stay ends with the parent on the Private Life route.

metadata.section_title: Conditions of grant as a child born in the UK to a person on the Private Life route

chunks.text:
### Conditions of grant as a child born in the UK to a person on the Private Life route

1.   PL 25.1. The grant of permission will be subject to the following conditions: 
    1.   (a) work is permitted; and
    2.   (b) study is permitted, subject to the ATAS condition in Appendix ATAS; and
    3.   (c) if the decision maker is satisfied that: 
        1.   (i) the applicant is destitute, as defined in section 95 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999, or is at risk of imminent destitution; or
        2.   (ii) there are reasons relating to the welfare of a relevant child which outweigh the considerations for imposing or maintaining the condition (treating the best interests of a relevant child as a primary consideration), or
        3.   (iii) the applicant is facing exceptional circumstances affecting their income or expenditure,

    4.   then the applicant will not be subject to a condition of no access to public funds. If the decision maker is not so satisfied, the applicant will be subject to a condition of no access to public funds.

2.   PL 25.2. For the purposes of PL 25.1(c) ‘relevant child’ means a person who: 
    1.   (a) is under the age of 18 years at the date of application; and
    2.   (b) it is clear from the information provided by the applicant, is a child who would be affected by a decision to impose or maintain the no access to public funds condition.
chunks.summary: Under the Private Life route, children born in the UK to applicants can receive permission allowing work and study, with exceptions if they face destitution, welfare concerns, or exceptional circumstances; in such cases, public funds access may be permitted. The decision considers the child's welfare and under 18-year-old status.

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for settlement as a child born in the UK of a person on the Private Life route

PL 26.1. A child applying for settlement as a child born in the UK of a person on the Private Life route must apply online on the gov.uk website on the specified form: “Settlement as a Child (including a child aged over 18 already in the UK as a dependent).”.

1.   PL 26.2. An application for settlement must meet all the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) any fee must have been paid; and
    2.   (b) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided a passport or other document which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must be applying as a child born in the UK of a person (P) on the Private Life route who: 
        1.   (i) has made a valid application for settlement on the Private Life route that has not been decided; or
        2.   (ii) is settled or has become a British Citizen, providing P had permission on the Private Life route when they settled, and the applicant was born before P settled; and

    5.   (e) the applicant must be in the UK.

PL 26.3. An application as a child born in the UK of a person on the Private Life route which does not meet all the validity requirements for settlement may be rejected as invalid and not considered.

metadata.section_title: Suitability requirements for settlement as a child born in the UK of a person on the Private Life route

chunks.text:
### Suitability requirements for settlement as a child born in the UK of a person on the Private Life route

PL 27.1. The applicant must not fall for refusal under Part Suitability.

PL 27.2. DELETED.

PL 27.3. The applicant must not fall for refusal under SUI 5.3. of Part Suitability, unless the applicant has completed a qualifying period of 10 years with permission as set out in PL 27.5 and has spent at least 5 years with such permission since the end of their sentence.

1.   PL 27.4. Where any of the following occur during the applicant’s qualifying period for settlement, the applicant must be refused settlement unless the applicant has completed a continuous qualifying period of 10 years with permission under PL 27.5 and has completed 5 years continuous residence with such permission after the date of the first grant of permission after the suitability ground came to the attention of the decision maker: 
    1.   (a) involvement in a sham marriage or civil partnership (SUI 8.1. of Part Suitability); or
    2.   (b) use of false documents or information or deception (SUI 9.1. and SUI 10.1. of Part Suitability); or
    3.   (c) litigation debt owed to the Home Office, unless the debt has been paid (SUI 17.1. of Part Suitability); or
    4.   (d) debt to the NHS, unless the debt has been paid, or the total value of outstanding charges is under £500 (SUI 16.1. of Part Suitability); or
    5.   (e) the applicant has breached the conditions of their permission (SUI 11.1. of Part Suitability).

2.   PL 27.5. Where an applicant must complete a qualifying period of 10 years (under PL 27.3. to PL 27.4.), they must have had permission as one or a combination of the following for that 10 year qualifying period: 
    1.   (a) entry clearance or permission granted as a partner or parent under Appendix FM (except for permission as a fiancé(e) or proposed civil partner); or
    2.   (b) permission described in the Home Office grant letter as “family permission as a parent” or “family permission as a partner”; or
    3.   (c) permission on the private life route under paragraph 276ADE or 276BE(2) before 20 June 2022 or Appendix Private Life; or
    4.   (d) entry clearance or permission as a child of a person with limited leave as a partner or parent under Appendix FM; or
    5.   (e) permission granted outside the rules as a partner, a parent or child or because of private life on the basis of Article 8 of the Human Rights Convention.

3.   PL 27.6. The applicant must not be: 
    1.   (a) in breach of immigration laws, except that where the Exceptions for overstayers section of Part Suitability applies, that period of overstaying will be disregarded; or
    2.   (b) on immigration bail.
chunks.summary: Applicants seeking settlement as a child born in the UK on the Private Life route must meet suitability criteria, including not falling under refusal grounds and, if relevant, completing a 10-year qualifying period with permission. They must also be refused if involved in sham marriages, deception, unpaid debts (except NHS charges under £500), or permission breaches during this period, unless they have met specific residence and permission duration thresholds.

PL31.1. Unless an exemption applies (for example where the applicant is aged under 18), the applicant must show English language ability on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages in speaking and listening of at least level B1.

PL 31.2. The applicant must show they meet the English language requirement as specified in Appendix English Language.

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application for settlement as a dependent child born in the UK of a person on the Private Life route.

PL 33.1. If the decision maker is satisfied all the suitability and eligibility requirements for settlement as a dependent child born in the UK of a person on the Private Life route are met the applicant will be granted settlement.

1.   PL 33.2. If the requirements for settlement are not met, but the decision maker believes the applicant is likely to meet all the suitability and eligibility requirements for permission to stay as a dependent child born in the UK of a person on the Private Life route, the application will not be refused, but will be varied by the Secretary of State to an application for permission to stay as a dependent child born in the UK of a person on the Private Life route. Where this happens: 
    1.   (a) no additional application fee for permission to stay will be required and the settlement application fee will not be refunded; and
    2.   (b) the Secretary of State will write to the applicant informing them of this variation and if required will request the applicant pay any Immigration Health Charge.

PL 33.3. If the applicant does not pay the requested Immigration Health Charge, or does not request and is granted a fee waiver for the Immigration Health Charge, the application for permission to stay will be rejected as invalid.

PL 33.4. Where an applicant is granted permission to stay, they will be granted for the period as set out in PL 24.1, subject to the conditions in PL 25.1.

PL 33.5. If the decision maker is not satisfied that the applicant meets all the suitability and eligibility requirements for settlement or permission to stay as a dependent child born in the UK of a person on the Private Life route, the application for settlement will be refused.
